meanings.sent1: The naughty cat would harry the poor dog every day.
meanings.sent2: The telemarketer continued to harry the homeowner with calls.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel liked to harry the birds in the garden.
meanings.sent4: The relentless rain seemed to harry the travelers on their journey.
meanings.sent5: The persistent mosquito would harry me all night long.

meanings.sent1: The bandits planned to harry the village under the cover of darkness.
meanings.sent2: Vikings were known to harry coastal towns for their treasures.
meanings.sent3: The raccoons managed to harry the campsite for food scraps.
meanings.sent4: The storm seemed to harry the fields, leaving destruction in its wake.
meanings.sent5: The pirates would harry passing ships for their cargo.

meanings.sent1: The children would harry to the playground as soon as school ended.
meanings.sent2: The wind began to harry the leaves across the yard.
meanings.sent3: The excited puppy would harry around the house in circles.
meanings.sent4: The river seemed to harry downstream with great force.
meanings.sent5: The busy ants would harry back and forth carrying food to their nest.
